conclusion: The problem involves determining the temperature of an ideal gas at state C, given the temperature at state A, the internal energy change, and the pressure-volume relationship on a p-V diagram.
The temperature at state A is given as \( T_A = -73^\circ C = 200 \) K (using \( T = 273 + \text{temperature in }^\circ C \)).
The internal energy of the gas changes by 200 J during the process from state A to state C.
The volume of the gas at state A is \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \mathrm{m}^3 \).
The volume of the gas at state C is \( V_C = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \mathrm{m}^3 \).
The pressure of the gas at state A is \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \mathrm{Pa} \).
The pressure of the gas at state C is \( P_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \mathrm{Pa} \).
The gas constant is \( R = 8.31 \, \mathrm{J/(mol \cdot K)} \).

premise: The process from A to B is isobaric (constant pressure), and \( P_A V_A = P_B V_B \).
conclusion: The process from A to B is consistent with the diagram, confirming it is isobaric.

premise: The process from B to C is isochoric (constant volume), and \( \frac{P_B}{T_B} = \frac{P_C}{T_C} \).
conclusion: The process from B to C is consistent with the diagram, confirming it is isochoric.

premise: Using the ideal gas law \( PV = nRT \) for state A, \( \frac{P_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{P_B V_B}{T_B} \).
conclusion: The temperature at state B is \( T_B = 800 \, \mathrm{K} \).

conclusion: The temperature at state C is \( T_C = \frac{1}{3} \times 800 = 266.67 \, \mathrm{K} \).
